Because your job is distracting your brain  I'm exactly the same  Face deep in legal essays for uni for three days and nothing  Finally lay down with an movie and my heart starts palpitating  It's just anxieties nice way of giving us a wave with a wicked grin while saying 'still heeeeeere   didn't think you could get rid of me that easily did you '
Sadly it's one big chain reaction  People hurt others because of the ways they've been hurt before  You can only try to break the chain by not being the next link  Try not to let the way people treat you change the way you treat others  Try to not take it personally but understanding everyone is just broken and lonely and struggling and don't take the behavior of others as an assessment of your own value  If some totally random person walked up to you on the street and attacked you  I hope you'd be more likely to assume it was some crazy person out of their mind rather than "my god  what did I do to provoke that "  You have to try to look at other situations like that to  Someone being rude to you or disappointing you in some way doesn't necessarily mean you did anything  It's healthy and mature to try to ask yourself if you did anything to cause it  but you don't want to cross that line so far that you seek ways to blame yourself when you didn't cause it

Hi pinkerton8   There must be some of this going around   I just responded to a question a lot like this the other day   I couldn't find my answer to that one  but if you're reading through other people's posts  you might see it   One of the things trauma does  especially based on the kind of trauma it is  is mess with our ability to judge situations and respond emotionally to them   Many people feel numb and dissociated  others "overreact" to everything around them   Working through what happened to you and being able to express your feelings around that  will help you to re establish balance in responding to other things in your life    It's not unusual to go from "I don't feel anything " to "I'm feeling EVERYthing and can't stop "  Oftentimes our inability to feel is actually repressed fear of ALL of those overwhelming feelings underneath coming out     Experiencing feelings during non personal events  like movies  books  other peoples experiences not close to you  lets you know that your "feeling meter" is intact   It just isn't ready to work on  your  stuff right now   Journaling about when you  do  feel  whether to a movie or seeing a bird in your yard or anything else  can help you start down that path   You can begin to  bring that into therapy and talk about the situations where you do have feelings   That will probably help find a lot of clues to helping you to feel in the more personal areas   So  for now  just notice where and when you do have any kind of feeling  sad  mad  glad  etc   and jot down the situation   Eventually you'll see a pattern that might help your therapist to bring you out more   All my best 
I cancelled my NYE trip to Iceland due to not yet recovering from anxiety

I laugh at dark depression or mental illness jokes particularly when they come from someone who also struggles with it  Maybe it's a coping mechanism  maybe it's just a way of hiding how real it is 
I lost my dog recently and it hurts so bad but I do the exact same thing  It confuses my family 
I had a FB profile before with all my acquaintances and friends from elementary school and high school and etc  I gradually stopped posting anything and was less and less tagged in pictures or posts over the years  When I got to college  I just didn't get the point of it and I would just waste my time looking at a feed of people I didn't like or know and every birthday I would get self conscious that I got less messages than the previous year  So at my last semester I deleted my FB  I was out of FB and most social media for a solid 4 months  Then I started university and work and somehow I felt a necessity to connect to the people I actually cared about so I made a new one  Got about 60 friends  all of which I know and talked to  I still don't post anything  I merely only have it for Messenger  But tell you what  I don't care  Scrolling a feed thay doesn't have random people's status and likes all over and just generally seeing stuff I'm interested in has made my FB experience much better  So my advice  Do some cleaning  Remove people  just stick to a small number of people you like  It won't matter if you don't post  none of it will matter actually 
Yes  pretty normal  Most people don't exist at one emotional level constantly  Many of us go through periods of feeling better and hopeful and then coming back to the depression   Don't think that your mom showing concern means you need to cover this all up and pretend it's not happening  She'd probably feel better knowing the truth about how you feel and being able to help you  The fact that she right away asked if you needed to talk to somebody shows that she was willing to help  and you instead took that as a sign that you should lie and deny it  Nobody can start forcing pills down your throat or making you do anything you don't want to  all you have to do to start out is talk to somebody  If you want to make your mom feel better  you can still be honest about how you're feeling but just reassure her that it isn't that she did anything wrong and you aren't about to go jump off a building or anything  you just feel down sometimes

Pretty much exactly what you did here  I would recommend trying to sit down and write out some of what you are feeling  because in the moment in person to person conversation it can be a bit tricky to remember everything you'd like to say  Prepare a description of what's been going on while you are in the comfort of your own home so you can just bring it with you and hand it to them  Their first question is going to be what brings you here and what are you hoping to get out of it  so you might as well have your answer ready    In terms of your concern that you'll just have medication thrown at you  it's possible  Especially if it's a psychiatrist and not just a therapist  The one time I saw a doctor of the type who can write a prescription  they barely listened to me and I walked out with a script for medication a few minutes later  Therapists are different  they are there to engage in talk therapy and behavioral counseling  All you can do is attend the appointment and see what type of person this doctor ends up being  If it's clear that they're just a pill pusher  you'll have to probably look elsewhere if you'd rather do talk therapy

Yeah  without real enforced consequences it can be hard to change  I too am someone who didn't benefit from parents who knew when to be strict  They helped me in all the wrong ways and refused to help in the ways I really needed    The irony though is that you seem to have the insight about why that alternative style of treatment would be better for you  and you seem keenly aware that you'll never get it from your parents  so you might some day have to just play pretend and decide to parent yourself  Even in his meek empty threat there is some truth to it  there will be consequences for your inaction some day  even if it's not until they are dead and gone and can no longer help take care of you  I know trying to imagine your own consequences isn't the same as actually having someone to play that role in your life  But so many of us will never have the parents that we wish we had  You'll either have to push yourself with your understanding that some discipline would be better for you  or whatever comes of your life you can fall back on blaming that your parents didn't use the right style of parenting  but at the end of the day it'll be your life in the future and nobody will excuse you for the failings of your parents    I'm sure it's hard to be a parent and to know when to implement tough love  You talk about wanting to mature but then even within this very argument it's a shuffling of blame onto how other people failed  You could get in the fast lane to maturing by accepting you're gonna have to enforce these rules on yourself and make the changes that you'd like to see    But yes  it is disabling to have parents who didn't know when to be firm

Be honest with your doctor even though I know it's scary to say some of these things out loud  Describe exactly what you said above  describe the physical effects you may be feeling  They may get you a referral and they may write you a prescription  There are a lot of different treatment paths and the one you take is ultimately your choice  I went for help finally at the beginning of October  I've been back every 4 weeks since to follow up with my treatment plan  Don't be discouraged if the first thing you try doesn't work the way you want it to  If you are prescribed something  you will likely be started on the smallest possible dosage and the work from there  If you are referred to someone for therapy there may be a bit of a wait  You may be prescribed some immediately helpful but short term drug like lorazapam or other fast acting drug to get you through the immediate time until you find a more permanent solution that works for you  If you feel you aren't being heard or understood  reiterate to them whatever you need  I don't know you but I'm proud of you for going to get help for this  It's hard  it's scary  Depression has the awful ability of making you feel like you don't deserve the help  You do  You deserve to feel like your best possible self  Good luck

Any update on how your doing   I my self suffer from childhood trauma   The way my childhood has now affected me  is in my attachment style  sounds a lot like you have the same one as I do  avoidant dismissive attachment  i e  Shuts down  self sabotages  As well as a host of other issues like boundaries issues    communication problems     It's easier said then done  As I have the same problem and am still trying to figure out how to not do this myself  but one way not to sabotage yourself relationship is to communicate to your partner how you're feeling  and let him know your feeling feeling  Feeling secure in the relationship will help you not be active in sabotaging it    Hope this helps  and good luck   Another great tool is therapy   
One of the best ways I've found to help with perfectionism is to switch where you focus  Focus on   progress not perfection      I know that you know that being perfect is an unachievable goal  Even things that seem perfect on the surface  such as a perfect teacup  or a perfect performance   really aren't so perfect if you start to examine them harder    A much more reasonable  and achievable   goal is  progress   Becoming a bit better every day    Another tip is to   shift your focus to your breathing    I think this subreddit already has some tools based around mindfulness meditation  Mindfulness is a game changer because it gets your brain in the habit of being in the present moment  instead of worrying about the future    It's not full proof  nothing is   but it really does help

 I can tell you that Xanax is a controlled substance and highly addictive  That being said  xanax is the least concerning of scripts I've seen  I would say something to your pharmacist  OR call your doctor and inform them if the pharmacist is making criticizing or inappropriate remarks  It just takes one phone call from a doctor explaining the legitimacy of scripts to shut it down  It sucks that you have to  but the amount of people abusing all of the legitimate medications that we actually need  is overwhelming

I had something similar  although not as extreme  when I was younger  At around 19 years old or so I realized me and everyone I knew was going to die some day  The realization of that was crushing    I had been getting into samurai philosophy  and so I stole a technique from the samurai who were known to be pretty fearless when it came to death  I practiced a death meditation    The basics of it is you imagine yourself dying in a variety of different ways  Being crushed to death  shot  sliced  swept away in a tornado  etc      This  admittedly  was very uncomfortable for a long time  But after a few months I conquered my fear of death   Part of that process was also figuring out what I thought happened when you die and being comfortable with that fact    I actually recorded an entire podcast about my experience using this meditation  I know we aren't suppose to link stuff  but maybe you will find it to be useful  http   www brilliantside com conquer fear and anxiety using this samurai technique bsp 014

I've managed to get a 3 92 this semester all the while being depressed  panicking  going through a break up from a long term relationship and constantly thinking I was losing my mind  Don't ask me how I did it because I honestly don't know  Last semester felt like a haze  I barely applied myself and didn't learn the way I wanted to  I just memorized for the sake of doing well on assignments exams  You have 2 days left  If you can live through depression  you'll find a way to power through these next couple of days  My final exams were about two weeks ago and Let me tell you  it was not easy studying for Thermodynamics   Stat  Mech  I realized what was at stake and fought off any distraction and tendency to self loathe and give in to that familiar feeling of being numb that depression manifests itself as  Study the material as if it was a cure to your depression  Don't worry about anything else for now  I'm rooting for you buddy  Easier said than done but boy was I relieved after giving it my all despite my afflictions 
I've stopped trying to get better  I'm in maintenance mode  So basically just trying not to do suicide ideation too much    coping with the cycles  bipolar  which pretty much just consists of keeping my emotions as muted as possible so I don't hurt others or make any stupid decisions       It's less stressful this way   I'm comfortable knowing that I'm no longer setting myself up for disappointment  about 15 years of seeking treatment only to feel worse about myself each time  but I do realize that it's pretty fucked up that my baseline standards are "don't kill yourself" and "try not to ruin your life even more "

You finally meet someone you really hit it off with and every day you look forward to sharing a new experience together  Then one day things slow down  The person is suddenly busier than normal  stops initiating communication  and all you're left with is a vast hole once occupied by hope and love  You feel intense loneliness which is only amplified by the happiness of those around you  You feel like that was your only chance at connecting with someone so deeply  and that if this didn't work out  there's no way you'll get so lucky again  I know exactly how it feels because I've gone through the exact same thing  More than once  And you probably will to   The disappointment and pain never gets better the second time around  It's crushing to feel so strongly toward someone and not have it reciprocated  in addition to losing them  it's also a hit to your confidence  But there is so much more out there than that one person  Hit the gym  keep up those grades  find a new hairstyle  join a club  take a trip outside the country  You will be surprised how much will change and how much  you  will change in the next few years  You will remember this as simply a blip in the past  Just keep at it   we're rooting for you

Nicely done   I think that small victories are actually a HUGE part of recovery because I think  more often than not  we take little steps towards wellness rather than huge strides  Those little steps stack up over time until one day you realize how much better you've gotten from a year or two ago    For instance  it was my first day of grad school today  something I was already feeling a bit anxious about  and I found out yesterday that I was exposed to norovirus on New Year's Day  A few years ago this would have sent me into a total anxiety spiral and I probably would have made myself feel sick from anxiety  but I actually managed REALLY well  I was able to reassure myself that it wasn't likely a bad enough exposure to truly get sick  and even if I DID wind up getting sick  I recognized that I could survive it and power through  even if it was really unpleasant   I managed to enjoy my first day of school without worrying about it at all  and guess what  I'm out of the 48 hour window without any symptoms so I'm probably totally fine    This probably seems like a huge victory but to me it feels like a small one  because it was one of many little victories in a long journey of recovery  It was essentially the next logical step towards wellness    So yes  Celebrate the small victories  because they add up to MASSIVE victories in the long run  and always be forgiving of yourself when it comes to setbacks  because it's all part of the process too

I have the exact same issue  I try to challenge it as much as possible and make my life as "normal" and enjoyable as I can  but at the end of the day the same irrational fear and panic absolutely dominates my day to day life  the big victories do feel very empowering though  and I make it my goal to chase that feeling of being able to conquer anything as you say   I've managed to visually suppress it to the point that only family and close friends know or can tell I have it  but it doesn't change what is going on inside my head  It's not exactly easy but I can look completely relaxed while having a full blown panic attack  It's probably the most annoying part of all of this  because while I can apparently pull off leading a "normal" life and appearing that way  people don't get to understand how hard that is for me to do unless I tell them about it  and even then most people don't understand what it is  how it affects me or how to help  So it's best kept as a silent struggle to most

By the time senior year rolled around in highschool all my friends since middle school had pretty much abandonded me  i had zero people to hang with  my SA was so severe I avoided people at all costs   During lunchtime when everyone else was having lunch with their friends  including the friends i once had  i roamed the corridors with no one to talk to   I was so ashamed to be seen by anyone like this that i hid in the bathroom stalls until lunch was over   I didn't even want to be seen in the library   I felt alone  forgotten  desperate for any sort of interaction  yet too petrified to even reach out just to say hi to anyone out of fear of rejection and reliving the ridicule i faced in the past   This happened for pretty much my entire senior year  alone in that stall   I couldve left at any time but the mind has a way of creating it's own prison out of past traumas we don't understand   I mean i still dont have friends but christ if i wasn't so afraid i mightve found a club to do some kind of activity with that year  How does this relate to what you went through   Don't know  maybe i'm still not over it and i hope it gives you some perspective 
Definitely  We are creatures of habit and that goes for everything we do  Even having negative thoughts and shutting yourself away can become an addictive habit once you get stuck in that rut  Understand that it's not you as a person that is being like that  it's the routine you're stuck in of being cynical and automatically thinking negatively about things    I've been in the same situation for 10 years and am only just realising that and getting help to get out of it  You can do it

Hi  Yes  this is a common symptom of anxiety  sometimes called 'air hunger'  I get it at seemingly random times  and it's horrible  I suspect it has to do with long term breathing habits  For example  being anxious and stressed might cause you to breathe shallowly for long periods of time  without realising it  and then you have an episode of air hunger  Could also be to do with posture  or muscles  or stress hormones    Or all of those  Take your pick

Thank you for answering  I guess the stigma and discrimination has a lot to do with it  
Of course it's normal to feel anxious about certain things  like an important event such as an exam or a job interview  The problem   an anxiety disorder   starts when someone begins to feel anxious abnormally or irrationally   I would argue about the curable uncurable aspect of these disorders  I was diagnosed with severe generalised anxiety disorder and depression years ago  I've used several medications which didn't help at all  and then I went through cognitive behavioural therapy which did indeed help  but it's still pretty bad and definitely still severely affects my quality of life   Most people who are prescribed the medication react positively  and on top of this CBT can help a lot in terms of coping mechanisms and staying out of the trap that anxiety disorders leave in your brain  So anxiety disorders are definitely very treatable  but I wouldn't say they are curable  If someone has an anxiety disorder  it will take either prescribed medication or a cognitive effort to continually suppress it throughout their life

disagree with the other posters  i tried the medication route  with 2 different medications  and the side effects were scary  it was genuinely a better option to just deal with my normal depression   i have a friend who is a biomedical engineering PHD student at Cornell  and he told me to avoid these medications as it's not fully understood just how they affect the brain  i ignored him  but i realized later that he has a great point   I know i'll get a lot of flack for my viewpoint here  but please understand that i'm speaking from personal experience as well as educated consultations   if this is your first time seeking therapy  sounds like it is based on your post   and you like her  then give her a chance before you start down the road of the for profit pharmaceutical industry  i'd say give it a few months and see if you notice any improvements  if you really are still struggling then  then medication may be worth the try 
Go back and get some counselling dude  maybe see someone different  At the end of the day  they're not there to give a fck about you  and they're not pretending to either  Their job is to analyse your issues from the outside and advise you how to fix them  because your head is not clear enough to do it yourself   Speak to some friends as well and just be completely honest with them  Trust me  I've been hiding my feelings for the last 10 years and putting on this mask of the funny nice guy  I'm only just starting to talk to friends about it now and I'm so surprised with how understanding they are being  You'll be surprised too  Speaking to people is a massive help  And if you go to a doctor they may prescribe you something to help you temporarily lift yourself up  and once you've done that it will be easier to fix your problems   Godspeed

How come 
If you're worried about schizophrenia  then you're probably not developing schizophrenia   Most people who develop psychotic disorders aren't aware that they are doing so   they lack "insight" into their own illness  The fact that you're worried in the first place is a good indication that you're NOT developing a psychotic disorder like schizophrenia   The fear of schizophrenia  meanwhile  is a VERY common fear in people who struggle with anxiety  I myself dealt with it for a long time  and still occasionally do  It feeds directly into the fear of losing control that so many with anxiety issues have   Rest assured that you likely don't have schizophrenia  and even if you did  you probably wouldn't even be the first to notice

Hey mate  I hear you  I did seven days a week  eight to twelve hours on weekdays and six on weekend for three years  It really fucked me up in more ways than one    Here's the thing  We live in a time where a steady job is a luxury  That  however  does not mean that you have to abuse yourself to do it  Trust me  no stakeholder benefits from a workaholic    My advice to you is to set limits  Work diligently for six hours every day  Set daily tasks that you need to accomplish  Screw around the rest of the time if you feel like it  but just clock in the six hours  Daily    The thing is that humans are only productive in six hour increments  That is why slave labor ranging back to Ancient Egypt relied on the number of bodies to do the job rather than on the skill of individual workers    And lastly  for the love of god  get a a hobby that you enjoy and devote time to it  I made a huge mistake when I gradually quit everything I  used to  enjoy for the sake of "recovering" from the day's labor    Good luck   Edit  Also  I would like to point out that you admit that you're not doing work tasks  but rather screwing around on the Internet  Don't worry  I've done that too  but realize this  If you start doing your  job  for six hours every day  it will make your life much  much more enjoyable  You will  I assure you on this  feel better about yourself and the job at the end of the day if you do the six hours in

feel like no one cares  It's okay to feel this way  But the world would be a much more sadder place without you  Think of your mentally ill mother and your baby sister  How would they feel if you killed yourself  Heck  I am a random stranger on the internet and I would feel fucking devastated if you killed yourself  The world is a wonderful place  Believe me  Most of the time it feels like shit but there are corners of the globe you havent seen yet and its gorgeous  There could be a chance you might travel some day and get to see the rest of the world dont die before then  There is a chance you will fall in love and get married and have kids  There is a chance you will meet your soulmate one day  There is a chance life will get bettter  Dont die before then  As long as you are alive you have chances  As long as you are alive you have options and you have the possibility of change  You have the chance to change your life around and make yourself happy  As soon as you die all of that is gone  Death is lonelier than life  You will rot in your grave with worms eating you  While you are still alive there is still time to reach out and communicate with others who feel the same way you do  Look at this sub  You are not alone  You know the main benefit of staying alive  You can stay and help other people who suffer the same way you did and help them save themselves    You are indeed severely depressed from the sounds of it  There is treatment there is therapy you are not gonna feel this way forever  This too shall pass my friend  Everything passes  The main mistake that we make is thinking our sadness will last forever  But it doesn't  The sun still rises every day  So will your sadness pass away and a new day shall begin  Hold tight friend you can do it  Please try to Anxious feelings and an anxiety disorder are two completely separate things  Everybody will feel anxious at some point in their life  not everybody will have an anxiety disorder  That said  this is a support sub so if you don't believe that anxiety disorders exist  this is not the place to discuss it  I encourage you to open your mind and speak to sufferers of anxiety disorders to educate yourself before making harmful blanket statements that serve no purpose other than to stigmatize mental illness

I have experience going cold turkey with paroxetine  which is another SSRI    I felt the same pulses in my head  I heard strange zapping sounds in my head and felt them too  'Zap    'Zip '  it was like hearing my neurons communicating with each other  really uncomfortable experience     The best thing you can do is to sleep it off  I slept maybe 15 hours a day for the first few days going cold turkey  Eating sweets and drinking a lot of water also helps    Most of the withdrawal symptoms went away within 1 week for me  but it took 1 month to get rid of the head pulses

I feel like I know what you're talking about  The utter hopelessness of  "well  this is me for the rest of my life"  can be soul crushing  even in the good times when you think  "ahh  I feel good today but tomorrow I will be back to my normal  sad  self"   The feeling that the good times are too fleeting and forever waiting for the inevitable downturn  Personally I feel that these thoughts will never ever truly go away  life is just too turbulent to be happy all of the time  In my experience the thought of "That's it I've won  no more depression for me" is a dangerous one as it only works to make the next downturn worse  Therefore it is important to learn as much as you can in the bad times   and   the good  making the conscious effort to gain new insights into yourself   to disgustingly over simplify  recognising what makes you sad  what makes you happy  what kind of thoughts start to enter your mind when you feel yourself on the precipice of no return  what changed in  your life  that brought you out of your episode this time  what changed in  yourself   what happened today that you feel good  how can that be repeated  The list goes on  In short  I don't believe that anyone 'just gets better'  their ability to deal with it does when they are open to adapting their way of thinking      When you say 'stuff' what do you mean  Psuedo normal 'life' stuff  paying bills finding a job building or maintaining relationships  or are their particular extenuating circumstances in your life that would be hard for anyone to deal with  In either case it is not a weakness to feel weak  True strength is found in ones ability to  endure   a trait that I personally hold in a higher regard than many others as it transcends the circumstances of the individual and provides a window into the integrity of their character   Now you talk of not being being able to cope on an evolutionary level  Where I understand your statement and have thought similar things myself  I would argue that the successful evolution is built on two defining traits    1  The ability to adapt   2  The ability to endure  The very fact that you undergo this battle every day  despite the fact  you do not always feel like you're winning shows that on an evolutionary level  you are doing exactly what you need to do    As a sidenote I would say that comparing yourself to others is inherently unhelpful  I e  " x  isn't bothered by  y   so why does  y  bother me so much  I must be a pussy"  and just leads down a road of self perpetuating internal resentment  We are all on this arduous march my friend and we all have our strengths  even if we ourselves cannot see them    I hope I've managed to address some of your issues  I've drawn quite a bit from personal experience and hope I haven't missed the point   All the best

You know those prank electric buzzers  That people could hide in their hands and then you get shocked and OUCH  And then next time you see them  they offer to shake your hand  but you're a little wary about it  It's kind of  sort of  a little bit like that    Except maybe you were shocked really badly  or maybe shocked a lot over a long period of time  and now sometimes you get angry about it or depressed about it because it really sucked and it feels unfair that it happened    Or sometimes you're out minding your own business  having a good day grocery shopping or whatever and then you see somebody's hand and suddenly your heart rate goes up and you flashback to being shocked and all you want to do is leave the store and hide hide hide hide until you feel safe  Or maybe kick them or scream  But mostly hide   Or you're sound asleep but wake up in a cold sweat with heart pounding for the third time that night and you desperately wish you could just fucking forget about it    Or you have to go to work and everybody thinks handshakes are no big deal  so you try to act like it is no big deal  and logically you even know it is no big deal  but your body keeps reacting with strong fear responses like it is a BIG SCARY DEAL  Tight chest  racing heart  goosebumps  feelings of dread  trembling  sometimes more or less symptoms that may or may not be visible   So you try various medications  therapies  coping strategies  etc to try to get back to "normal" so you don't have excess stress after  aka post  a trauma    from your post traumatic stress disorder   I can't speak for everybody but that metaphor is about the best I can come up with  Just replace electric buzzer with situation s  more physically and emotionally painful than anybody ever wants to experience

that's fair  but understand that maybe she isn't "restricting you in what you want" but rather  she's using her education   knowledge of her field in determining that medication isn't the best option   i took effexor  and then wellbutrin  effexor completely took away all feeling  and gave me erectile dysfunction  which was awful as I had a gf at the time  wellbutrin was much better  at least at first   but then after about 2 months i started getting even worse anxiety than before  got so bad i had to leave work early some days  and curl up in my bed  couldn't even leave to eat dinner  it also gave me really bad rage  as i threw my phone against the wall and shattered it after some friends made fun of me  was a huge overreaction  and this is what ultimately led me to realize that the medicine isn't for me  can't say that i'm doing great today  but i don't have the crippling anxiety since i stopped the medicine   also understand that  at least for wellbutrin   the generic version does nothing  i was told  through forums  and my psychiatrist  that the brand medicine was the way to go  which runs  1500 per bottle    luckily i had good insurance  but still cost  50 per bottle for me   anyway  keep an open mind and get the facts  don't discount your therapist  like i said  after a few months  if you think therapy alone isn't helping  then just get referred to a psychiatrist through your general physician and he'll help you

This happens to me  My grandmas dementia was very bad and although my mum seems in perfect health I get terrified  I think that what you're saying about her being forgetful and misplacing things is very normal but your anxiety is making you hyper aware  And for some positive news  doctors are very close to finding medication that allows us to control things like dementia in the same way that we would diabetes  In the mean time encourage her to take up a healthy diet  regular exercise and some quality sleep 
I'm aware that it's possible and for many people it can definitely be treated to the point where it does not exist  And that could definitely be defined as being "cured"  I would love for that to be the case for all sufferers  but until it is I can't personally blanket these disorders as curable  I can't say it's curable while I've suffered from it for almost a decade   As for going through life  I feel like I live a very good life and my anxiety disorder is probably one of the only real problems I have  It is intertwined with absolutely everything I do and if I'm doing something new or even just slightly different  it's always very difficult  There are less than a handful of places I feel safe  secure or comfortable   I guess I'm just speaking from personal experience   this disorder has plagued me for a long time with absolutely no end in sight  I fight extremely hard just to have a semi normal existence and it's never ending and incredibly draining

Loneliness is normal    Everyone gets lonely when they spend too much time with themselves  introverts do this a lot more often  I'm 24 and I've felt very lonely at 17  All I wanted was this girl that I was in love with but she didn't want to be with me    I started drinking a lot with my couple friends and going to parties just getting drunk off our asses and not caring about anything other than having fun  It helped with anxiety and it relieved some of my social awkwardness but it was a double edged sword like most things are  I've done things I'm not proud of while inebriated and it has shaped a skewed view of things in my head that I'm still trying to chisel out and remedy   Instead of drinking  taking drugs and just in general participating in risky behaviour I would advise you to start a hobby or begin learning an instrument or taking up a sport and being persistent in one or more of these endeavours  The benefits you get from meeting new people and engaging in new social circles are tremendously important in shaping you as an independent and stable human being  You also get a lot of satisfaction from the process of improving at what you're doing no matter how slow it  is   You WILL meet new and interesting people who WILL get you and WILL want to hang out with you by just going out and participating in things you truly like or are passionate about  Don't look for friends by how they look or if they're popular or whatever  go do something that interests you and talk with people who are interested in the same things as you  it's how you will find people that have similar thought processes and appeals as you do  Be brave  Take up a pottery class  Anything really

Yes  It became so problematic for me that I had to stop drinking caffeine for almost 2 years  I cut out coffee  sodas with caffeine  even chocolate  I'm just now able to slowly drink a bit of it again  I started by drinking decaf coffee  decaf coffee DOES still have caffeine  just very little  then half caf  now I can have a very small cup of regular coffee once in a while   So yes  it can cause anxiety  because it is a stimulant  If it becomes very bothersome  try cutting back on the amount  If that doesn't help  cut it out completely

Lately I've been sleeping up to 20 hours a day  day after day  I haven't been able to go to school  shower  eat  or even get out of bed  It's a typical occurrence in depressives  and it's horrible to be in  One thing I'd suggest though is taking something to help you sleep around ten or eleven and getting a full night's rest  keeping to a proper sleep schedule can often make it easier to get up and out the door 
Antidepressants only have an effect on 30  of people who try them  If it's been three months  I suggest talking to your doctor about trying another medication  It can be daunting to think about having to taper off one medication and start another  not knowing how it will effect you  but it's worth it when you come across the perfect drug or combination  It took me around 6 years to find the perfect combination  with several suicide attempts and hospitalizations in between  Looking back  I'm thankful I stuck it out because the medications I'm on now are life changing

I've been reading a book about anxiety  and in the book they say that anxiety disorder is not a mental illness   We have a fear that we will go crazy or lose it when we have a bad panic attack  but it is not actually going to happen   It's completely normal that you can't think rationally in a state of panic    The adrenaline spikes  and your body goes into fight or flight mode    We live in a fast paced stressful world  and more people than you know deal with some sort of anxiety disorder   People with anxiety disorders are normal  we just can't handle stress as well as others

High school can be a drag because most of the classes are required and you're set on some unilateral path  it feels forced  College is way different  Think about it as a way to find yourself and what you're interested in  It's the beginning of your adult journey really  You mentioned a bunch of subjects  Look forward to being able to take the most diverse classes you can find your first year   take psychology and computers  and anything  You'll find something that you lean towards and enjoy   As far as right now goes  volunteer somewhere or find a cooking class to try  Ask your high school teachers or guidance counselor where to look for those kinds of opportunities in your community  
From what you say  I don't think giving medication a shot would be a bad idea  I recently started taking medicine for anxiety  lexapro   the first day or two I felt hungover to be honest  but since then it has helped a lot  Hopefully you have a good doctor and they won't be just guessing your medication  My doctor asked me a lot of questions about my lifestyle  concerns  habits  all kinds of stuff to help get me on the right medicine  I'm sure as you let them know what you're worried about they can work with you    also  if it helps at all  they almost always start you on a very low dose  and then bump you up after a few weeks if all is going well  This hopefully would help you to notice any side effects before you are at a dosage where it might become a problem    I'll also say that I feel way more like myself than I have in a long time since I started medication  I don't feel numb or anything  my emotions are the same but I can handle them way better     Edit  I forgot to add that last bit

Great job  OP  You could have saved someone's life  
  Freeways are tough because you are "trapped" between exits  That is what I'm struggling with  but I'm getting better  I've pushed on to a few more exits now  4 in a row is the most   I thought it would kind of 'level' out but the anxiety is still gradually increasing with each passing exit    I think once you know that you are ok to drive the car if the anxiety hits you feel more and more confident  I'm not sure I'll be doing interstate travel anytime soon  but its so very nice to at least be able to get onto the freeway  I was basically frozen at the entry before   Were I live has horrible traffic and the freeways are pretty well full 24 7  so I figure if I can make them here than I should be able to do it anywhere        The trick if anyone from the future is reading this  Do one exit and keep doing it  Do it 5 times in a row  have a break for an hour do it again 5 times in a row  Then keep doing it  Do it every single day  Even if you do one exit 50 times if you can make that one exit without the anxiety spiking than its much easier to carry on 
It was good for anxiety  it did cause some digestive issues but they weren't intolerable  but it made me manic when we pushed the dose too far  Shortly after using it I experienced psychotic symptoms for the first time  After that came the worst depression of my life   If we had stayed at 20 mg vs pushing to 30 and not have gotten rid of an adjunctive mood stabilizer I think it might have been OK and worth holding on to  YMMV

My insurance has hoops I need to jump through    First step is going to your primary  They won't prescribe you meds you need unless it's like ibuprofen on a flu med  Everything else needs a specialist    Then they tell you to call psychiatry to make the initial appointment with a  social worker   Those are easy enough  Except the person put words into my mouth and I had to correct them a million times  They need to write that you need meds and that you need therapy  Can't get just one at the same place  And this appointment was just medical history and such which could be looked up by a click of a button  Since my medical history is in their system   Then you go to make appointments  For meds they need to make a psychiatrist appointment  For therapy  a psychologist visit    Psychiatrist is only a month wait  At which rate I haven't had my meds since August  And everyone just keeps assuming I somehow have them still  But they only prescribe you things    Now you need a psychologist visit for therapy  Those are 2 months wait  And that's just whoever available first    So now the latest appointment they can make is during your work hours because  like them  you have an 8 4 30 job  I have to spend   each appointment while missing income  I can't take a lot of time off from work or I won't have a job therefore won't have insurance   But the social worker did give me a nice printout of suicide hotlines  in case I decide to do something crazy  because it's not like the psychiatry department can help me anytime soon  Oh  and I'll need to prove to the psychiatrist that I do  in fact  need the meds and would like them back  But wait  they don't prescribe one of my old meds by this provoder  Which means a new drug all together or none at all   So here's me with my psychiatrist appointment later this month and a therapist appointment next month  I wonder how much longer do I get to be miserable  Because no meds since August is rather bad

Hallo nochmal    Hello again    How are you today  Would you like to tell more about the SNAFU    Not feeling motivated is very common during depression  and understandable considering what you have been through  You may feel exhausted and hopeless  like nothing is worth doing  You may feel afraid to try anything in case it brings more pain  None of this is fun  but you're not alone  Try to remember that you are still loveable even if you achieve nothing  And maybe there is a small bit of wisdom in your lack of motivationperhaps people in your life are pressuring you to do things you don't want to do  Sometimes we rebel by becoming apathetic  because deep down we know we are meant to do what pleases us  and not just what impresses others

Much use those are  Look through the posts  There are many poets per day with people calling and the person on the other side either hangs up  tells you to such it up and that it's not that bad  or even to go do something crazy   Hotlines exist  But they're not filled with trained psychologists who give a damn or at least try to 
Hyper ventilation can actually cause this  Especially if you're worried about your breathing you tend to breathe more than you need to  reducing the C02 content in your blood a lot and making your breathing rhythm weird  might feel like you can't take a breath  elevated heart rate etc    It's not harmful at all and is normally regulated by the body but with anxiety you can focus on it too much and prevent your body from getting back into its rhythm   Try taking deep breaths through your nose  holding for 4 6 seconds and breathing out slowly through your mouth  Having a conversation with someone also helps as when youre concentrating on that your body takes over your breathing 
It took me a few tries but I have a good team of doctors   The lab work found mine and with the supplements she recommended I m feeling so much better   But please dont start taking any until you get the workup done  vitamin poisoning is a very real thing   Be smart  good doctors that don't want to force you into a starvation diet or invasive surgery do exist

Yes  caffeine makes me more anxious  If I drink a lot of tea in a short amount of time  I will also become very anxious   The cure  besides cutting down on caffeine  I find that taking salty food or isotonic drinks help to mitigate the anxiety  You can try adding some salt into your water to drink

You don't have to go to university right away  And once you're not going straight from high school to uni  a lot of schools have mature student status which can override any missing credits  or offer ways to make up for them  I felt so similar at your age  I felt so pressured to take the right classes and pick the right college program  and I ended up hating the program and dropping out because my anxiety and ADD were getting so bad from all the pressure  I started working full time at a coffee shop and worked up to a retail job that was a lot less stressful  and now I'm back to the same coffee shop franchise because that retail job ended up being a lot of unsafe work environments and abusive managers  I'm in a dump and feel trapped in the fast food industry  but if there's anything good it's that I don't have a degree being unused weighing down my shoulders and I have all the time in the world to pick what I want to do  Seriously  college is a giant ball of stress and there's no shame in taking time to think about it when you don't have the pressure of graduation on your shoulders
